Twenty-Eight Attend Assembly;
Compulsory Ruling Readopted
Scoring optional assemblies as
absolute failures, Edward Sadtler,
president of the Student Council,
announced yesterday that next
week's assembly, to be devoted to
the public initiation of 0. D. K.
with Carlyle Barton as guest speaker, will be compulsory.
Because he feared a poor attendance, Sadtler cancelled yesterday's
assembly, which was to feature an
address by the Hon. William E.
Sweet, former governor of Colorado, on the "New Deal."

classes in the affairs of the University, he believed that only
through assemblies could such an
interest be revived.
"If the students do not take advantage of this weekly opportunity
to keep in touch with affairs on the
campus, the next step is to compel
them to come," he declared.

Urging the appointment of some
Marylander to the proposed national commission to !study the entire
field of aviation in the United
States, Senator Tydings and Representative Cole of this state made
a recommendation to President
Roosevelt this week of those men
Who would be most acceptable.
President Joseph S. Ames, who is
chairman of the National Advisory
Board for Aeronautics, was among
the four named by the Congressmen.
Asserting that Maryland, and
Baltimore in particular, are leading other communities in aviation
manufacture and development, the
recommendation said of the four
rnen suggested: "We earnestly urge
the choice of one of these, or his
selection would be an eminently
Outstanding one and his contribution
to the cause one of value."

Jays Face Breather For Second Successive Week; Entire Squad To Be Used
For the second Consecutive week,
Coach Van Orman will pit his
charges against an opponent which
is capable of offering little more
than a workout for the title-bound
Un,iversity of PennsylJay ten.
vania will be the foes at Homewood
tomorrow.
Tomorrow's game may see the
return of George Packard to the
Black and Blue fold at his usual
center position. Packard has not
been out for lacrosse due to intensive work on his graduation thesis.
George appeared as soon as his
studies were completed and will
probably see action Saturday. His
return to the Hopkins ten will
greatly enhance their chances
against Maryland and St. John's.
Regulars Back

Henry Beeler, Pete Reynolds,
and Charley Orth, who missed the
Swarthmore fray because of the geology trip, will also be in the starting line-up tomorrow.
So far this year the stick play of
Penn has been mediocre and powerless. They opened their current
season- by defeating their Alumni,
3 to 2. They then lost to Lehigh
and were swamped by Navy. On
paper the Jays seem to be in for
another breather, but as all the
northern teams point for the Hopkins game, an interesting battle will
probably be in store for the spectators.

ture Their First Victory
Of The Current Season
Facing Catholic University at
Homewood in their fourth meet of
the season tomorrow, the Jay track
team will attempt to capture its initial victory of the year.
The Black and Blue so far has
dropped encounters to Swarthmore
and Delaware and has been tied by
Haverford. The margin of defeat in both cases, however, was
extremely small and the contest on
Saturday is expected to be just as
close as the preceding ones.
Hopkins has met Catholic U. for
the last four years, with the Jays
winning in 1930 and last year, and
Catholic U. triumphing in 1931 and
1932. Last season, the Washingtonians had only an informal squad,
but the sport has been revived and
it is thought that they will present
their constomarily powerful aggregation.
Catholic U. has shown its greatest strength in the field events,
while Hopkins is favored to win the
distance runs.

Advice To Car Owners
A successful remedy to prevent
autos from cavorting around streets
without consent of the owners has
been placed in use at Southern
Methodist University.
A cardboard notice was found
recently hanging on one of the cars.
It read:
"You are welcome to borrow this
car, but please have it back at the
time agreed above. Please put in it
at least as much gas as you use."

former Hopkins lacrosse star, it
was natural for Philip Wilson
Swindell, better known as Pete, to
come to Hopkins upon his graduation from Gilman.
Besides being on the stick team
at Gilman, Swindell also attained
first string berths on the football
and basketball teams. In his last
year Pete captained the Indian team,
and held down a berth at wing defense.
Swindell has made a favorable
showing for himself, considering
the fact that this is his first year
here. Last fall he proved himself
to be a valuable cog in the Hopkins
football team.
It was during the Mt. Washington clash that Swindell distinguished himself as wing defense.
He and Pasarew saved the day for
Hopkins by stopping the threatening onslaught of Lorne Guild, Hillman star.
With the Wolfpack pelts hanging on our belts, says Pete, our two
remaining threats are St. John's
and Maryland. Although both the
Terps and the Johnnies have been
taken into camp by the Hillmen,
they are still dangerous contenders
for the national stick title.
Swindell bids fair to become one
of the country's most outstanding
stickmen in his three remaining
years of lacrosse at Hopkins.

Urging the appointment of some
Marylander to the proposed national commission to !study the entire
field of aviation in the United
States, Senator Tydings and Representative Cole of this state made
a recommendation to President
Roosevelt this week of those men
Who would be most acceptable.
President Joseph S. Ames, who is
chairman of the National Advisory
Board for Aeronautics, was among
the four named by the Congressmen.
Asserting that Maryland, and
Baltimore in particular, are leading other communities in aviation
manufacture and development, the
recommendation said of the four
rnen suggested: "We earnestly urge
the choice of one of these, or his
selection would be an eminently
Outstanding one and his contribution
to the cause one of value."

Jays Face Breather For Second Successive Week; Entire Squad To Be Used
For the second Consecutive week,
Coach Van Orman will pit his
charges against an opponent which
is capable of offering little more
than a workout for the title-bound
Un,iversity of PennsylJay ten.
vania will be the foes at Homewood
tomorrow.
Tomorrow's game may see the
return of George Packard to the
Black and Blue fold at his usual
center position. Packard has not
been out for lacrosse due to intensive work on his graduation thesis.
George appeared as soon as his
studies were completed and will
probably see action Saturday. His
return to the Hopkins ten will
greatly enhance their chances
against Maryland and St. John's.
Regulars Back

Henry Beeler, Pete Reynolds,
and Charley Orth, who missed the
Swarthmore fray because of the geology trip, will also be in the starting line-up tomorrow.
So far this year the stick play of
Penn has been mediocre and powerless. They opened their current
season- by defeating their Alumni,
3 to 2. They then lost to Lehigh
and were swamped by Navy. On
paper the Jays seem to be in for
another breather, but as all the
northern teams point for the Hopkins game, an interesting battle will
probably be in store for the spectators.

ture Their First Victory
Of The Current Season
Facing Catholic University at
Homewood in their fourth meet of
the season tomorrow, the Jay track
team will attempt to capture its initial victory of the year.
The Black and Blue so far has
dropped encounters to Swarthmore
and Delaware and has been tied by
Haverford. The margin of defeat in both cases, however, was
extremely small and the contest on
Saturday is expected to be just as
close as the preceding ones.
Hopkins has met Catholic U. for
the last four years, with the Jays
winning in 1930 and last year, and
Catholic U. triumphing in 1931 and
1932. Last season, the Washingtonians had only an informal squad,
but the sport has been revived and
it is thought that they will present
their constomarily powerful aggregation.
Catholic U. has shown its greatest strength in the field events,
while Hopkins is favored to win the
distance runs.

Advice To Car Owners
A successful remedy to prevent
autos from cavorting around streets
without consent of the owners has
been placed in use at Southern
Methodist University.
A cardboard notice was found
recently hanging on one of the cars.
It read:
"You are welcome to borrow this
car, but please have it back at the
time agreed above. Please put in it
at least as much gas as you use."

former Hopkins lacrosse star, it
was natural for Philip Wilson
Swindell, better known as Pete, to
come to Hopkins upon his graduation from Gilman.
Besides being on the stick team
at Gilman, Swindell also attained
first string berths on the football
and basketball teams. In his last
year Pete captained the Indian team,
and held down a berth at wing defense.
Swindell has made a favorable
showing for himself, considering
the fact that this is his first year
here. Last fall he proved himself
to be a valuable cog in the Hopkins
football team.
It was during the Mt. Washington clash that Swindell distinguished himself as wing defense.
He and Pasarew saved the day for
Hopkins by stopping the threatening onslaught of Lorne Guild, Hillman star.
With the Wolfpack pelts hanging on our belts, says Pete, our two
remaining threats are St. John's
and Maryland. Although both the
Terps and the Johnnies have been
taken into camp by the Hillmen,
they are still dangerous contenders
for the national stick title.
Swindell bids fair to become one
of the country's most outstanding
stickmen in his three remaining
years of lacrosse at Hopkins.
